so, you made a blob with 3 different stats... I just had an idea off of that, what if the default blob was actually white and gained RGB to indicate the 3 traits a blob could have, Spontaneous Generation Rate, Death Rate, and Replication Rate...

In order to have any Spontaneous Generation, they have to have one instance of a blob with that RGB value,

Now, I realize you're probably wondering what the difference in SGR and RR is if both need a blob to exist to initialize it...
For that, I shall put forth that SGR does not scale with your blob count like Replication Rate does, and so it's basically a static part in the formula so long as a single blob exists, where RR is a function

Now, I put forth the concept of the RR and SGR being on a sort of point scale, where if it wants to move toward one, it has to draw points from the other... however, taking points out of one isn't the only way to get more points for the other... This is where we incentivize death rate increases to prevent evolution for just shooting for 0 due to not dying just being the best possible way to increase your population...
Increasing death rate is what gives a blob "Evolution Points" to "spend" on replication and spontaneous generation, as being able to reproduce requires energy, energy consumption will eventually lead to death

YOU NEED precision information in the DNA to build useful protein shapes. Where does that information come from? .... random copying errors? Constructing a protein is not like assembling a Tonka toy. The number of possible arrangements of only left handed amino acids  in even a relatively short protein chain easily leaves human comprehension in the dust. You want hemoglobin? You need to be absolutely dead on target or the protein will not fold into the required shape.  Natural selection is comatose. No foresight, no hindsight and no goal. It is a slave to a random process. It doesn't "select" anything. The fittest survive...quite by accident  That's all she wrote. The theory is incorrect. The mutation lottery is utterly and unceasingly unreliable. The fossil record and macroevolution are antithetical... as they should be. That was of great concern to Darwin. His concern was well founded.. Sudden appearance of species and stasis remain the norm.      Wishing everyone good health. Health is wealth.

Again this isn't evolution. Its a study on replication and its affect on survival. Mutations do not equal a new creature. Wish he would stop mixing up micro-evolution with macro-Evolution. Also, He makes the claim the coding for different traits (like color) were not present but his model assumes they are and that's why they have the chance to change that trait. This is a variation not a mutation. The clue to this is the idea the blue can mutate repeatedly into green and red and the red can repeatedly mutate into orange. A mutation is random in what it changes. This means the change has an incredibly low chance of occurring more than once. So low in fact it would be eieser to guess a 5 thousand digit pin on the first try. Additionally, mutation often mutations leads to death of the individual preventing replication of the mutation.  Most mutations cause issues with evolution, as would be shown by the first experiment. The last part about RNA is completely wrong. Its a misused information.

"In this video, we see how mutations can lead from simple replicators to complex organisms." - I've only seen a simulation where you arbitrarily chose some mutation rates and reproduction rates, you've set up your creatures according to your rules. Then you've got amazed that the rules you've made did what you've expected. Then you've just stated that this is how complex life forms can emerge. No proof, no explanation, nothing, just a single statement. You have not explained how sexes could have emerged, even though you've stated "Eventually we will tie this to the real physical world, stay tuned", but that never happens. "Since complex organisms can't form without replication it doesn't matter how good they are at replicating if there aren't any around to replicate." and so "we were left with a mistery" and learned nothing about evolution theory. So which was first, the chicken or the egg? And how did the rooster get into the picture?

We are almost certain the first replicators were not RNA, phosphosugars do not occur in nature, and even if they did their linkage would need to be catalyzed. It's far more likely the first replicators were PNA or TNA molecules, which are even simpler than RNA molecules. While we have gotten RNA molecules to self-replicate in the lab if their length is between 50-100 nucleotides, we are still working on PNA replication, so the question is no where near settled!

See this is great, except that it is entirely unscientific if you're trying to equate this to inter species mutation. There is no paleontological or archaeological evidence for one species mutating into another. There are NO fossil records in between different kinds of species. Mutations like these do NOT account for different kinds entirely. The darwinian finches are still finches. They're not now frogs. Natural selection works, but evolution as people like to say it does, does not. There's scientific evidence for evolution, as in species adapting to/mutating to better live in certain conditions, but all of those are from one thing to then the same thing. If what you're suggesting is true, then somehow things like chickens mutated out of fish or other sea based creatures. Before that, somehow single cell organisms mutated into muti cell organisms down the line into fish. Before that, somehow single cell organisms came to exist. Before that bacteria... If you back far enough, there's just hot rotating molecules and elements.. How do those randomly get put together in such a way that creates life? So let me ask a version of the age old question, what came first? What randomly mutated first... The fish's gills, it's brain, it's skeletal structure, it's internal organs, or it's reproductive system? Which one of the absolutely necessary things for a fish or other sea creature mutated first? They would have had to mutate all at the same time PERFECTLY, but we know that's not how that happens. Or that even when incredible mutations to a living thing's dna do happen, they almost exclusively make life more difficult and not easier. This theory you're presenting is telling us that were supposed to believe that massive mutations that produced things like brains and vital organs all happened randomly at the same time in such a way that the mutated form of life is now the only living form of that creature AND there is no actual measurable physical or empiracally verifiable evidence for the MANY stages in-between these different forms of life? How are we supposed to believe that? Evolution only accounts for mutations and adaptations limited to a singular kind of animal (human, iguana, frog, etc). That being said, your math is extremely applicable to mutations and helps us understand mutations such as the color and hair color or beak shapes or things of that nature, and why we have the specific forms of the animals alive that we do today! Not trying to bash your content, but it's important to only be teaching verifiable truth. If it's just speculation, like you do BRIEFLY mention, there should be much more emphasis on it. "We are only beginning to understand exactly how this fits into our real world situation," or whatever the exact quote that you said in this video was, is simply not enough. Therefore, I say, don't misrepresent what you're giving as more accurate or widely applicable than it truly is.

The concept is fine, but the piece I disagree with is that mutate a single-celled organism into an extremely complex multi-cellular organism from genetic mutations. There’s no natural advantage to mutating 10% of a centriole. In order for cellular reproduction to occur, you need to have 100% of a centriole. There never was and never will be a mutation that will give you an entire functional centriole, let alone two. In other words, with these extremely complex systems in even just single-cell organisms, let alone multi-cellular organisms, EVERYTHING needs to work at once. You can’t just mutate a tenth of it, because there wouldn’t be any advantage to it, and in most cases you would just die. Macro-Evolution is broken, Micro-Evolution is plausible.

Fascinating video. Many years ago I experimented with evolutionary concepts using two creature types: predators and prey. I created an X-Y landscape and one of the characteristics of every creature was its location on the X-Y grid. I had arrays to keep track of the two creature types. With every iteration, each prey stood a chance of dying, based on a basic random chance, it's age, and it's proximity to a predator creature, and all these variables would increase or decrease the random chance. The only hard-stop was that every creature would die at age 20. For the predators, all the same life/death factors were the same except proximity to prey creatures. The closer they were, the more likely they were to get fed. I wrote this program in Basic on an APPLE II computer, that is how long ago I did this. For replication, I kept the number of creatures constant. After the die-off of creatures that did not make the cut, I repopulated their slots with creatures generated from the surviving creatures. I would randomly select two surviving creatures of that type, average their stats, and then add a small randomized positive or negative value to those stats. I then plotted the location of all creatures on the screen, on the grid. It was fun to watch the prey creatures evolve away from the predator creatures while the predator creatures evolved in hot pursuit.

The deep mathematical truths about life and evolution is that it has no matemathics at all, or at least they are so complex that human brain capacity can't express and process it mathematically.


Everything is based on conditions, usually a few thousand of them at once. Abstract things like death chance, replication chance, and mutation chance are absent, and if you really want to express it in graphs and whatever, you should start with boolean logic, especially IF statements. hard question, are mutations mistakes or not? I believe they are not, but are instead intentional to improve survival chance of a creature by putting for example 10% of its reproducing into gambles, meaning all you need is around 1,1x growth rate, where 10% turns into gambles. so by the time 10 creatures die, 11 must reproduce, and 1 of them will turn into a gamble. but ofc for survival going to need over 11 reproduced in that scenario as there are more factors. Overall point is, it seems unlikely it would have been nature's mistake that happens to be cause for evolution completely, but instead intentional of the primitive beings.

Um, sorry. When a species mutates, the result is a life form that cannot reproduce. Take birds or fish. Any of those species that reproduce with mutation have two problems. The mutations are most always fatal and even viable mutations have no other mutant with which to reproduce. Species are fragile, not hardy.

Further, when you think of chromosomes, animals have widely varying numbers of them. How can an animal with say 22 chromosomes mutate into an organism with say 30...and even if it did, that organism would have no way to reproduce.

We actually already know enough to explain how the first life emerged. Before there was life, space was just filled with different particles interacting with each other, according to physical laws. After some (long) time, eventually, there will be a lot of recurring patterns in how particles interact. They may bond together better with specific other particles, split up into different clusters, which can bond with other clusters and so on. There will be a lot of different types of clusters and patterns, but the ones which are the most stable and adaptive to different conditions, those are the ones that stay. So while other things fall apart, those things that dont fall apart get more time to "be", which is really all that existence is about. It is just about gaining more time to be. So the patterns which managed to stay, those are the ones that are around today. It is actually simple evolutionary principles, applied to atoms interacting with each other and forming clusters and patterns. Over time, the environment will force the patterns to become more complex and selection and competition will only leave the "best", most stable patterns to able to stay, to "survive". We as animals share a billion tiny patterns with other animals, some even with plants, others are unique to us, which is why we are not going extinct (hopefully). Evolutionary principles are inherent to the universe, it is a simple logical conclusion: That which manages to stay, is able to "be". Now "living" things might require closer classification, such as reproduction and movement, or life cycle and genetic material or something like that. Living things might also just be a part of the pattern "DNA", which is the actual thing that is struggling to survive. But the borders are not clear, after all, everything emerged from the universe by the same principles, they are just different patterns of matter with different strategies for how to keep staying around.
